status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works  Department is currently reconstructing Staniford and Causeway Streets.  In addition we are allowing some utility work to be done before the final paving is scheduled. When completed it will be a major improvement for  the pedestrians, cyclists and motorists who travel these street daily. We acknowledge the construction is a major inconvenience to the public. We have police details called in every day. They obviously will help with traffic control and public safety. You will also notice more jersey barriers and barricades in use to help guide pedestrians and traffic through and around the work zones. We have asked the contractor to restore all pavement markings within their work zone even if they have not disturbed the markings. This means that all crosswalks/ double yellows/skip lines/ arrow onlys etc will be maintained throughout the project. All temporary pavement markings will be completed by November 6th. We ask for your patience while this major project takes place. For any questions or concerns, please contact the project engineer Kay Barned-Smith at 617-635-4951. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Thank you for your comments regarding the Hempfest, also known by its organizers as The Boston Freedom Rally. . The Boston Parks and Recreation Department has legally challenged on multiple occasions dating back to the 1990s.  The courts have allowed the event to continue despite our concerns over illicit drug use, damage to park property, and amplified music.  We must respect these court decisions and the First Amendment rights of the participants.   For those who have suggested that the event be moved to another park location, please note that the organizers specifically request that the event be held on Boston Common and we have no say in that part of their application. . We will continue to work with the City of Boston Law Department to discuss our options moving forward.  Your support and input is invaluable to this process.  We are currently collecting written comments that we will present as discussions of this matter move forward. . Please understand that we are constrained by past legal decisions interpreting this as an event protected by free speech but we will continue to work to mitigate impacts on the Common and the community as best we can. . Chris Cook. Commissioner.
description: This pot festival is so loud and obnoxious and has been going on for 2 days until 8pm. I don't get what they are protesting. Everyone is smoking pot an no one is getting arrested. Next year can we make this a 1 day or no day protest so My neighbors and I can enjoy our neighborhood without the screaming and yelling of this awful band. Why isn't there a noise ordinance or something

description:
Pedestrian signals on the North side of the Mass Ave / Huntington Ave intersection (traffic flowing westbound on Huntington Ave) have bad timers. 

When the light goes green, the countdown for pedestrians starts at 22 seconds. Around 16 seconds, the countdown stops and changes to the solid red hand. This is quickly followed by the lights for Mass Ave traffic going green. 

Either the pedestrian signal needs to allow for the full 22 second countdown, or the timing display needs to match the actual timing of the signal.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Several site visits have been made to this school by BTD and BPS Transportation in the past.  Our primary goal is pedestrian and school bus safety.  Having said this,  school warning signage was updated as was the school bus parking regulations.  Your request to install the "Do Not Enter Signs" will not yield the results you are looking for.  The bus operation closes the street by default as it has been since this school been in operation.  Furthermore, this section of Walnut Ave is a designated school zone which includes a school warning sign at Walnut/Townsend warning the driver they are approaching school grounds.  This school zone also includes school zone flashers in front of the school so drivers are more cautious (or should be) driving in this section of the roadway.  If the traffic congestion  is a results by the parents parking on Walnut Ave illegally then BPD and BTD can enforce the area.  Thank you for your concern.
description: Need a do not enter sign For the time of 9:15 to 9:30 school. Buses come down between that time and traffic is severe.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. Eversource Electric is installing a new transmission line on your street. This will improve the reliability of electrical service in South Boston. The contractor is McCourt. The transmission line work requires more plates than usual do to the complications of this type of work. We told the contractor McCourt though we acknowledge securing a large amount of plates is not easy it has to be done. They need to berm the plates properly every time they leave the job, this will require them to wedge the plates, pin them, and tac weld problem plates when necessary. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) regularly inspects the work and has found for the most part they are in compliance with our rules and regs. We met with them recently and reviewed our procedures especially regarding plates, and we feel that you will have less complaints about loud noise. The City acknowledges this is a major project and is an inconvenience to the residents of the street and we appreciate your patience and cooperation. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
